feed.title: Combined summary - BIP 2 promotion to Final

entry.title: Combined summary - BIP 2 promotion to Final
entry.summary: The discussions revolve around Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) and their adoption by the entire Bitcoin ecosystem. The proposed soft-fork in BIP 2 can only become final if there is no hard-fork with potentially-majority support, or at most three months have passed. However, the definition of "potentially-majority" is unclear, raising questions about a possible veto by a shop owner on a hard-fork expected to be adopted by the entire Bitcoin economy. Discussions emphasize the need for a consensus on proposed changes before implementing them to avoid fragmentation and potential issues with the network's integrity. The low barrier of use for forums used for comments is crucial as it allows for greater participation and flexibility among authors. Jorge Timón raises concerns about attackers who could prevent a BIP from reaching final status, while Mustafa Al-Bassam proposes a definition for when a hard fork becomes active. However, Timón points out that an attacker could easily prevent a BIP from becoming final with little time or effort, which leads him to conclude that any hard fork BIPs are unlikely to reach final status.Luke Dashjr opens a pull request to move BIP 2 to Final Status, intending to apply its more specific criteria to itself. Anyone can review the latest draft BIP and provide any objections ASAP. If there are no outstanding objections on 2016 April 9th, it will be considered to have reached rough consensus and updated to Final Status by merging the PR. However, the definition of "potentially-majority" is unclear, and this raises questions about a possible shop owner vetoing a hard-fork.In an email sent by Luke Dashjr via bitcoin-dev on March 16, 2016, he stresses the importance of having a low barrier of use for forums used for comments. He compares two forums: the Bitcoin Wiki and the GitHub wiki but argues that neither of those two forums qualifies in that case. BTCDraks seconded the objection. The writer expresses an objection to "BIP comments" in BIP2 and suggests that BIPs should be self-contained. Instead, comments should be made using the Wiki feature at bitcoin/bips itself. External sources are bound to go stale over time as seen in a number of existing BIPs that have linked to expired content.In another email conversation, Dave suggests using Draft-BIP2's provision for authors to specify their own backup wiki as policy in all cases, eliminating the need for a backup wiki altogether. Discussions also highlight the importance of unanimous agreement in the Bitcoin ecosystem for hard forks to be successful. Uncontroversial hard-fork BIPs can make it to the final state once deployed, while controversial ones may never become universally deployed. It is naive to think that just because someone cannot think of an incentive for an attack, an attacker will never do this.In conclusion, the discussions emphasize the need for a consensus on proposed changes before implementing them to avoid fragmentation and potential issues with the network's integrity. The low barrier of use for forums used for comments is crucial as it allows for greater participation and flexibility among authors. Additionally, BIPs should be self-contained, and any external sources should be avoided to prevent them from going stale over time.
